image.altText: A burnt out unit.

items.synopsis: Victoria Police confirm an elderly man has died in a fire at a retirement village at Kilmore, north of Melbourne.

title.children: One person dead after fire at retirement village in Kilmore, north of Melbourne

image.altText: Naomoto Hikaru celebrates

items.synopsis: Former FIFA Women's World Cup winners Nadeshiko Japan get the points first up on day seven against Costa Rica. Coming up is Spain vs Zambia in Auckland and Ireland against Canada in Perth. Follow live.

title.children: Japan cruise to victory over Costa Rica - next up, Spain vs Zambia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: So, just the two goals for Japan, who are all but through to the last 16 after a second-successive clean sheet victory. Incredibly that was the first time Nadeshiko Japan have kept consecutive clean sheets at a World Cup in 35 matches. Japan has a whopping 24 shots in that game, 12 on target, so will they be a bit frustrated that they could only score two? Perhaps. But it's not goals that they needed tonight, just the three points. You'd think Spain will provide a sterner test next time out when they meet in Wellington/Ta Whanganui-a-Tara on Monday, but that's a then problem. For Costa Rica though, that's a second-straight defeat that essentially puts them out of the tournament.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Comfortable win for Japan

children.content: So, just the two goals for Japan, who are all but through to the last 16 after a second-successive clean sheet victory.
Incredibly that was the first time Nadeshiko Japan have kept consecutive clean sheets at a World Cup in 35 matches.
(Getty Images)
Japan has a whopping 24 shots in that game, 12 on target, so will they be a bit frustrated that they could only score two? Perhaps.
But it's not goals that they needed tonight, just the three points.
You'd think Spain will provide a sterner test next time out when they meet in Wellington/Ta Whanganui-a-Tara on Monday, but that's a then problem.
For Costa Rica though, that's a second-straight defeat that essentially puts them out of the tournament.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Pretty dominant performance from Japan in that first half. Japan had 14 shots to Costa Rica's two in that first half, with five on target for Nadeshiko Japan (none for Costa Rica). They had 59.4 per cent of the possession as well and are well deserving of their half time lead.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Half time: Japan leads 2-0 at the break

children.content: Pretty dominant performance from Japan in that first half.
Japan had 14 shots to Costa Rica's two in that first half, with five on target for Nadeshiko Japan (none for Costa Rica).
They had 59.4 per cent of the possession as well and are well deserving of their half time lead.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two in two minutes for Nadeshiko Japan! Lovely finish from an acute angle by Aoba Fujino, who picked up a loose ball on the right, worked her way into the penalty area and then slammed the ball past Daniela Solera, who just invited the shot by leaving a gap on her near post. Fujino needed no second invitation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 27' GOAL JAPAN!

children.content: (Getty Images)
Two in two minutes for Nadeshiko Japan!

Lovely finish from an acute angle by Aoba Fujino, who picked up a loose ball on the right, worked her way into the penalty area and then slammed the ball past Daniela Solera, who just invited the shot by leaving a gap on her near post.
Fujino needed no second invitation.

items.synopsis: Consumer inflation for the June quarter falls more than expected by economists, while the IMF warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation falls to 6 per cent as interest rate hikes dampen demand, ASX surges, IMF warns of economic challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Big miner Rio Tinto says net profit for the first half of the financial year has slumped by 43 per cent amid lower commodity prices. Rio says net profit for the six months to the end of June came in at $US5.1 billion ($7.5 billion) from $US8.3 billion ($12.3 billion) for the same time last year. Iron ore, copper and aluminium prices fell leading to a $US3.3 billion drop in earnings, although the bottom line was helped by increased iron ore sales. Iron ore prices fell by an average of 14 per cent and copper prices were 10 per cent lower over the half. Rio's earnings were also hit by an $US800 million ($1.2 billion) writedown of its alumina refineries in Australia. Investors get a lower dividend payment of $US1.77 a share, down 34 per cent from last year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rio Tinto says first half profit down 40 per cent

children.content: Big miner Rio Tinto says net profit for the first half of the financial year has slumped by 43 per cent amid lower commodity prices.
Rio says net profit for the six months to the end of June came in at $US5.1 billion ($7.5 billion) from $US8.3 billion ($12.3 billion) for the same time last year.
Iron ore, copper and aluminium prices fell leading to a $US3.3 billion drop in earnings, although the bottom line was helped by increased iron ore sales.
Iron ore prices fell by an average of 14 per cent and copper prices were 10 per cent lower over the half.
Rio's earnings were also hit by an $US800 million ($1.2 billion) writedown of its alumina refineries in Australia.
Investors get a lower dividend payment of $US1.77 a share, down 34 per cent from last year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market jumped as investors hoped the Reserve Bank will pause interest rate rises for the second month in a row. That's after the rate of inflation dropped from the March quarter to the June quarter as the price of petrol, electricity and domestic travel fell. However rents saw their biggest quarterly rise since 1988. The annual pace of inflation slowed to 6 per cent from 7 per cent. The ASX 200 index rose 0.9 per cent to a five month high with most sectors boosted by rate pause hopes. Banks, consumer firms, energy and technology all gained, although real estate stocks fell. Miners jumped after China promised more stimulus. The Australian dollar dropped 0.4 per cent to 67.63 US cents on the prospect the RBA will keep rates steady at 4.1 per cent next week. For a wrap up of the inflation figures, here's my colleagues Michael Janda and Rachel Puppazoni.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian shares rise on prospect of another pause in rates

featuredLink.title: Inflation falls faster than expected. Has the Reserve Bank already increased interest rates too far?

children.content: The Australian share market jumped as investors hoped the Reserve Bank will pause interest rate rises for the second month in a row.
That's after the rate of inflation dropped from the March quarter to the June quarter as the price of petrol, electricity and domestic travel fell.
However rents saw their biggest quarterly rise since 1988.
The annual pace of inflation slowed to 6 per cent from 7 per cent.
The ASX 200 index rose 0.9 per cent to a five month high with most sectors boosted by rate pause hopes.
Banks, consumer firms, energy and technology all gained, although real estate stocks fell.
Miners jumped after China promised more stimulus.
The Australian dollar dropped 0.4 per cent to 67.63 US cents on the prospect the RBA will keep rates steady at 4.1 per cent next week.
For a wrap up of the inflation figures, here's my colleagues Michael Janda and Rachel Puppazoni.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While the market is betting on a 70 per cent chance of rates staying on hold next week at 4.1 per cent because of cooling inflation, here's what the economists think. Nomura Australia's Andrew Ticehurst thinks the Reserve Bank will put rate hikes on ice for now because of the new data. "We now think this will provide the RBA with sufficient ammunition to deliver another 'pause' at its policy meeting next week. "However, we are reluctant to call the end of the hiking cycle at this point, and think it appropriate for the market to price in another 0.25 per cent of hikes over coming months, on a balance-of-risks basis." CreditorWatch chief economist Anneke Thompson says consumers have well and truly responded to the RBA's tightening measures. "This result has reduced the chance of a further cash rate rise at the August meeting. "It now seems that labour force data will become more crucial to the RBA's decision making. "The board will be hoping to see some softening in the unemployment rate, to reduce the chance of further pressure on wages." EY's chief economist Cherelle Murphy thinks the fall in inflation over the June quarter is a cause for optimism. "The slowing in the quarterly rates of price growth eases pressure on the Reserve Bank to raise rates again in August, with the data suggesting that its dozen rate hikes since May 2022 are working as planned. "But with inflation still far above the Reserve Bank’s 2-3 per cent target band, and some ongoing upside risks to wages and food prices, we are not out of the danger zone yet." Stephen Smith from Deloitte Access Economics thinks the Reserve Bank has gone too far in increasing borrowing costs. "Excessive inflation in Australia has mostly been caused by supply side factors, meaning that interest rate increases have mostly been ineffective at bringing inflation under control. "Rather, inflation has fallen as a result of repairs to global supply chains and an easing of import prices. "The Australian economy is softening dramatically, the pace of inflation has peaked and is moderating quickly, wage growth is not excessive and medium-term inflation expectations are not rising." However, Jarden chief economist Carlos Cacho told Alicia Barry on the ABC News Channel that the official cash rate could go to 4.6 per cent because inflation remains too high .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: To hike or not hike: that is the question

children.content: While the market is betting on a 70 per cent chance of rates staying on hold next week at 4.1 per cent because of cooling inflation, here's what the economists think.
Nomura Australia's Andrew Ticehurst thinks
the Reserve Bank will put rate hikes on ice for now because of the new data.
"We now think this will provide the RBA with sufficient ammunition to deliver another 'pause' at its policy meeting next week.
"However, we are reluctant to call the end of the hiking cycle at this point,
and think it appropriate for the market to price in another 0.25 per cent of hikes over coming months, on a balance-of-risks basis."
CreditorWatch chief economist Anneke Thompson
says consumers have well and truly responded to the RBA's tightening measures.
"This result has reduced the chance of a further cash rate rise at the August meeting.
"It now seems that labour force data will become more crucial to the RBA's decision making.
"The board will be hoping to see some softening in the unemployment rate, to reduce the chance of further pressure on wages."
EY's chief economist Cherelle Murphy
thinks the fall in inflation over the June quarter is a
cause for optimism

"The slowing in the quarterly rates of price growth eases pressure on the Reserve Bank to raise rates again in August, with the data suggesting that its dozen rate hikes since May 2022 are working as planned.
"But with inflation still far above the Reserve Bank’s 2-3 per cent target band, and some ongoing upside risks to wages and food prices, we are not out of the danger zone yet."
Stephen Smith from Deloitte Access Economics
thinks
the Reserve Bank has gone too far
in increasing borrowing costs.
"Excessive inflation in Australia has mostly been caused by supply side factors, meaning that interest rate increases have mostly been ineffective at bringing inflation under control.
"Rather, inflation has fallen as a result of repairs to global supply chains and an easing of import prices.
"The Australian economy is softening dramatically, the pace of inflation has peaked and is moderating quickly, wage growth is not excessive and medium-term inflation expectations are not rising."
However,
Jarden chief economist Carlos Cacho
told Alicia Barry on the ABC News Channel that
the official cash rate could go to 4.6 per cent because inflation remains too high
